column1: Which State ordinarily exercises jurisdiction in respect of crimes committed on board vessels?
column2: The coastal State
column3: The flag State
column4: All States enjoy such jurisdiction
column5: The International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea

column1: What is an act jure gestionis?
column2: Acts jure gestionis are those undertaken by States in a private capacity
column3: All purchases by the State are acts jure gestionis
column4: All acts undertaken by State corporations are jure gestionis
column5: All conduct undertaken by government officials in their free time is considered jus gestionis.

column1: Which of the following is a treaty-based human rights mechanism?
column2: The UN Human Rights Committee
column3: The UN Human Rights Council
column4: The UN Universal Periodic Review
column5: The UN special mandates

column1: Should treaties assume a particular form?
column2: Treaties should always be designated as such and assume a particular form
column3: Treaties should always assume a particular form, no matter how they are designated
column4: Treaties do not have to assume a particular form or designated as such
column5: Treaties have to be designated as such, no matter what form they assume

column1: What does the doctrine of incorporation suggest in respect of treaties?
column2: The doctrine of incorporation requires that all treaties undergo legislative transformation before they become domestic law
column3: The doctrine of incorporation does not require any further action at the domestic level
column4: The doctrine of incorporation treats treaties as inferior to domestic law
column5: The doctrine of incorporation suggests that ratified treaties automatically pass into the sphere of domestic law

column1: Is recognition of governments prevalent in contemporary international practice?
column2: Recognition of governments is very prevalent in contemporary practice
column3: Recognition of governments has largely been replaced by functional Recognition
column4: Government recognition is common in respect of rebel entities
column5: Only democratic governments are recognised in contemporary practice

column1: What is the major difference between naturalism and positivism?
column2: On the one hand, naturalism is based on a set of rules that are of universal and objective scope and on the other hand, positivism is based on a structured and coherent legal system that is created by States in light of their interests and desires
column3: While naturalism serves only the theory human rights law, positivism has a wider and more general scope
column4: Naturalism concerns the underpinning values of the international society, while positivism the international rules as such
column5: Naturalism is a school of thought advocated outside of Europe, while positivism is Euro-centric theory

column1: Is there any hierarchy or priority among the various methods of peaceful settlement of disputes?
column2: Yes, all the political methods (e.g. negotiation, mediation, inquiry, conciliation) should be exhausted prior to resorting to legal methods
column3: Legal methods prevail over the political methods, since they are binding upon the parties
column4: There is no hierarchy among these methods and the choice belongs to the disputing States
column5: It is a matter of an impartial third party to decide which method will have priority over the other

column1: Which of the following statements best describes the UN Human Rights Council?
column2: The UN Human Rights Council has the power to impose economic sanctions on a state for human rights violations
column3: The UN Human Rights Council scrutinises the human rights records of member states on the Council and each member state of the UN
column4: The UN Human Rights Council replaced the Economic and Social Committee of the UN
column5: The UN Human Rights Council consists of 27 member states

column1: What is personal (ratione personae) immunity?
column2: Personal immunity is afforded to all physical persons
column3: Personal immunity is that which is afforded in a personal capacity and hence does not cover conduct of the State as such
column4: Personal immunity is afforded only to particular persons irrespective if their conduct was undertaken in a private or public capacity
column5: Personal immunity is afforded to State officials for conduct undertaken in a public capacity

column1: Is there any hierarchy or priority among States under international law?
column2: Yes, the States that were the founding members of the United Nations are vested with more powers and authority
column3: Yes, the Permanent Five Members of the UN Security Council (UK, USA, France, Russia, China) are in a superior position than the other States
column4: No, all States are considered equal as sovereign States (the principle of sovereign equality, enshrined in article 2, para 1 UN Charter)
column5: Whether there will be any hierarchy among States is a matter of each international organization to decide

column1: Which philosopher called the idea of natural rights 'nonsense on stilts'?
column2: Alan Gerwith
column3: Emmanuel Kant
column4: John Locke
column5: Jeremy Bentham

column1: Is the unlawful homicide committed by Minister of country X abroad an act jure imperii or jure gestionis?
column2: Such conduct is a public act (jure imperii)
column3: Such conduct never attracts immunity
column4: Such conduct is a private act (jure gestionis)
column5: Such conduct is a public act but is shielded by immunity

column1: What is the function of the contiguous zone?
column2: The contiguous zone functions as security zone of the coastal State
column3: The contiguous zone is a zone, in which the coastal State may explore and exploit its mineral resources
column4: The contiguous zone is a zone in which the coastal State is permitted to prevent and punish infringements of customs, fiscal, immigration or sanitary laws
column5: The contiguous zone is a zone in which the coastal State safeguards its archaeological and historical objects

column1: What is the difference between political and legal means of dispute settlement?
column2: The outcome arising from legal methods, ie arbitration or adjudication by the ICJ, is final and binding upon the parties, whereas this is not the case with diplomatic methods
column3: The political methods are pursued upon the consent of then parties to the dispute, whereas the legal methods not
column4: The political means lead to a final settlement of the dispute, whereas this is not the case with the legal methods
column5: The legal methods of dispute settlement are pursued only in respect of significant disputes, whereas the political means are employed in all disputes

column1: What is a 'treaty' according to the Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties (VCLT)?
column2: Treaties are all agreements concluded between States, international organizations and non-State entities (e.g. corporations)
column3: Treaties are agreements concluded between States in written form and governed by international law
column4: Treaties are both the written and oral agreements between States
column5: Treaties are agreements concluded between States in written form governed either by international or domestic law

column1: Magna Carta was
column2: An agreement in 1689 which guaranteed freedom of speech in Parliament
column3: An agreement in 1215 between the King and his barons, which guaranteed certain protections for subjects
column4: A constitutional document in the 19th century guaranteeing the right to vote
column5: A document setting a complete Bill of Rights for England

column1: Are there any limitations to the incorporation of customary crimes under English law?
column2: There are no limitations to the incorporation of customary crimes
column3: Customary crimes must be contained in a multilateral treaty in order to be automatically incorporated
column4: The courts may freely incorporate customary crimes into the domestic sphere
column5: The situation is not clear-cut but an act of parliament would most probably be required

column1: What is the meaning of justiciability?
column2: Justiciability refers to the possibility of enforcement of a particular right by the relevant rights holders
column3: Justiciability refers to the just nature or cause of a particular right
column4: Justiciability refers to the courts' assessment of whether the non-enforcement of a particular rights conforms to principles of justice
column5: Justiciability refers to the obligation of a State to enforce a particular Right

column1: Which of the following statements is false?
column2: In the 1990's it became apparent the European Court of Human Rights had to be reformed because it wasn't examining enough cases
column3: In the 1990's it became apparent the European Court of Human Rights had to be reformed because the workload had increased
column4: In the 1990's it became apparent the European Court of Human Rights had to be reformed because it was a part time court that could not process the growing number of complaints
column5: In the 1990's it became apparent the European Court of Human Rights had to be reformed because of the growth in the number of individuals who could access the Court after the increase in the number of member states

column1: What was the particular advantage of UNSC Resolution 678 over a collective defensive action under Article 51 UN Charter during the Gulf War?
column2: Resolution 678 allowed the allies to attack Iraq with nuclear and chemical weapons
column3: Resolution 678 is narrower than the inherent right of self-defence under Article 51 UN Charter
column4: Resolution 678 was faster to adopt and negotiate.
column5: Resolution 678 is broader because it authorised the use of force with respect to any matter threatening the peace and security of the Gulf region.
